titleStmt.title: Designing for discovery: using web maps in the digital humanities

dhq:authorInfo.dhq:affiliation: Department of Digital Humanities, King’s College London

dhq:bio.p: Gethin Rees is lecturer in digital products and industries at the Department of Digital Humanities, King’s College London. He was formerly lead curator for digital maps at the British Library where he was also principal investigator of Locating a National Collection, a foundational project in the Towards a National Collection programme. From 2010-13 he was research associate in GIS on the Mapping the Jewish Communities of the Byzantine Empire project, at the Centre for Advanced Religious and Theological Study, Faculty of Divinity, University of Cambridge.

dhq:abstract.p: Web map interfaces such as OpenStreetMap or Google Maps share a set of visual and interactive features that are widely used for navigation and discovering information. Associated software components such as Leaflet or Google Maps Embed API have become the de facto standard for geographical visualisation in the digital humanities. This article examines how the needs of humanities researchers can inform the design of these web map components’ features. Visual analysis and discovery use cases for web maps are introduced based on the TaDiRAH taxonomy of digital research activities. Visual analysis offers researchers opportunities to gain geographical insights from patterns in humanities data. Yet visual features of web map components such as the Web Mercator projection and background mapping tiles are only appropriate for the analysis of certain regions and scales. A discovery use case is introduced with the aim of using the map to access research objects. The article argues that visual features such as vector representations and popups can be designed to guide the user towards accessing rich content beyond the map. This use case aligns with researchers’ experience of using web map components elsewhere and projects that wish to encourage usage of research objects. Web map components have expedited the process of creating visualisations. Yet their convenience has led to a lack of spatial literacy and critical reflection. The article argues that historical and wider usage should be considered when appropriating any form of visualisation. Examining the research process helps the design of visualisations to support use cases, guiding users in addressing the open-ended and complex questions of the humanities.

dhq:teaser.p: How can the needs of researchers inform the design of web maps in the digital humanities?

body.p:
Web maps based on shared standards and common design principles are part of a suite of technologies developed since the late-twentieth century that created new approaches to geographic information distribution and, most importantly, in the usability and ease of application development . Proprietary and open-source APIs, platforms and services provided by Google, Carto, Mapbox, OpenStreetMap and others have lowered the level of expertise required to create maps, opening up geospatial data to new audiences and uses. Web maps such as Leaflet or Google Maps Embed API are now a mainstay of digital humanities courses and research projects and have become the de facto standard for geographical visualisation. Stuart Dunn notes that the launch of web mapping platforms like OpenStreetMap (OSM) in 2004 coincided with the floruit of the spatial turn and, alongside Geographical Information Systems (GIS), web maps have been key to the burgeoning interest in geography amongst digital humanists through the developing Spatial Humanities . In 2025, they represent the most commonly used form of visualisation amongst digital humanists employed by five of the eleven winners in the DH Awards Best DH Visualization category since 2012 . Yet, whilst the application of GIS in the digital humanities has been subject to decades of critical reflection , the use of web maps has received scant attention with a few notable exceptions
. Indeed, web maps are commonly subsumed within the category Web or DH GIS . In acknowledging the complexity of visualisation from a humanities perspective, recent scholarship has emphasised the need for graphical forms… capable of expressing ambiguity, contradiction, nuance, change . This article asks whether the web map component offers a constructive, effective, or appropriate method of visualising humanities data. To do so, it examines how such maps could be used in the humanities research process drawing on the TaDiRAH taxonomy of digital research activities in the humanities to outline discovery and visual analysis use cases. TaDiRAH offers a formal classification of digital humanities research with the aim of helping scholars to find the tools and resources they are interested in. This user-centred design approach draws on perspectives from cartography and visualisation research and is illustrated by the use of web maps in two collaborative projects that the author contributed to.

div.head: Definitions and scope
div.p: The term web map component refers not to a single piece of software or service but rather to several software libraries that share core features. Maps, described variously as interactive, dynamic, or slippy, have become commonplace on the web since the 1990s. Coded in Javascript and displayed in web browsers, they consume geospatial data structured according to a set of standards set out by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) . Perhaps the seminal moment in the development of this technology was the release of Google Maps in 2005 . However, in 2025, examples abound and include Leaflet, Open Layers, MapBoxGL, Maplibre and Google Maps Embed API. User studies demonstrate that the predominant use of these maps is to aid movement and understanding of the physical environment . Tasks such as planning journeys and navigation fit within the revenue models of companies such as Google that are rooted in advertising locations for visits and gathering user data through GPS-enabled mobile apps . These web map components have been used to make data available in bespoke applications that are created by developers for individual projects, or platform-based applications such as Carto or Google’s MyMaps, that are more widely used . The web map component is defined by some core features that exist in all software implementations and that constrain possible uses. Visual and interactive features sit within a rectilinear container that can be embedded into an HTML web page.

Three visual features are considered core to the component namely tiles, vectors and projection. Tiles form the base or background images of the web map whilst vectors take the form of points, polylines, or polygons, commonly styled as markers or shapes that sit on top of tiles. Vectors’ underlying data consist of geometries, usually in the form of coordinates, and attributes, text, URLs, or other information attached to the coordinates. The final visual feature is projection, a cartographic method used to transform the curved surface of the earth so that it can be viewed on a flat, two-dimensional one such as a screen. Interactivity is possible through a circumscribed set of actions that facilitate two goals: update of the visual display and the retrieval and display of attribute data. The former is achieved through zooming and panning actions that adjust the position and focus of vectors and tiles on screen. Attribute data can be retrieved by clicking on a vector. Particular implementations of web map components may, of course, contain other features such as a title, north arrow, text search, or scale; however, these are not essential. Similarly, these components might be embedded within a broader web page that facilitates further interactions through filters, sliders or buttons.

figure.head: A view from a typical web map component: Leaflet displaying tiles from OpenStreetMap. (Source https://leafletjs.com/)

div.p: Visual and interactive features are bound together in an iterative process that consists of three stages: seeing the cartographic representation (perception), interacting with the cartographic representation to change it (motor skills), and thinking about the newly created cartographic representation (cognition) (; see also ). The web map component’s restricted, highly structured and discrete environment offers several advantages. Out-of-the-box functionality allows developers to visualise geospatial data quickly and easily without having to write bespoke code for visualisation and present the results in a format that is familiar and intuitive to users. Yet, the design decisions available to the developer are constrained, and familiarity leads users to expectations about potential use. The question how do people use Google Maps in everyday life is poorly understood despite the application being deeply embedded in people’s lives globally. This article takes this question as a starting point to examine the broader web map component and its use by expert humanities researchers specifically.

The aforementioned out-of-the-box functionality has led maps to feature in many tutorials that urge digital humanists to visualise their data . These tutorials pitch the component as a convenient method for digital humanists or developers to present data to other humanities researchers and as a tool for personal research based on the premise that visualisation stimulates geographical thinking and interpretation without the need to master complex GIS software. To name one example, the tutorial Using JavaScript to Create Maps of Correspondence presents a clear and easy-to-follow method of creating a map of historical data using Leaflet, encouraging us tothink about space and geography in ways that challenge historiographical assumptions . Whilst GIS provides powerful functionality in the form of complex queries or statistical and algorithmic analysis, the constrained functionality of the web map component makes it a technology of visual communication
. The ability to embed a map within web pages ranging from complex bespoke apps to simple blogs has led individuals, projects and organisations to draw on the component to support new ways of engaging with humanities data. This article argues that there has been a tendency to assume such presentation holds intrinsic value. A thorough investigation of how the component has been incorporated within digital humanities interfaces to date would undoubtedly have value but would emphasise the intentions of the developer. Instead, this article seeks to emphasise the user by examining the different possible ways that the web map component could be used in the humanities research process and the types of insights these uses might lead to.

div.head: Using web maps for visual analysis
div.p:
A substantial body of research has broken digital research in the humanities down into constituent primitives, basic functions common to scholarly activity across disciplines, over time, and independent of theoretical orientation
. Such primitives are similar to the activities defined within the design perspective of Don Norman as a collected set of tasks, performed together towards a high-level goal . The TaDiRAH taxonomy of digital research activities in the humanities outlines a set of connected sub-activities that attempt to encapsulate the research process as a whole . TaDiRAH defines interpretation–the activity of ascribing meaning to phenomena observed in analysis –as absolutely fundamental to research. Analysis, the process of extracting information from data, encompasses visualisation the use of graphical forms analytically in order to detect patterns, structures, or points of interest in the underlying data . Such visual analysis could be considered the primary or even sole use of web maps in the digital humanities. However, this article argues that web maps can also assist researchers in the activity of seeking out objects of research, research results, or other information . Referred to as discovery in the TaDIRAH taxonomy, the activity is associated with tasks like querying, searching, or browsing . Visual analysis and discovery are adopted as separate use-cases here as emphasising their differences offers a heuristic that can usefully inform the design of web maps.

It might be assumed that the primary goal in using any map is to gain geographical insight, and a wealth of cartographic research has examined visual analysis of maps in terms of map reading tasks or communication models
. In defining visual analysis, the article draws on the distinction between elementary and synoptic tasks made by Natalia Andrienko and Gennady Andrienko . In the digital humanities, a dataset is a model of a human phenomenon or behaviour that is derived from a research object or objects. Datasets model geographical characteristics of the phenomenon as coordinates. To offer insights, a map must offer a general view of the phenomenon’s principal parts , communicating the shape or a summary of the data. Visual patterns based on variables such as association, differentiation, arrangement, or distribution approximate aspects of the phenomenon through two-dimensional patterns including clusters, trends, boundaries, or outliers . Andrienko and Andrienko define the analysis of such patterns as a synoptic task: one based on viewing a set of data simultaneously to gain an insight that goes beyond the sum of individual elements . The generation of such an insight also rests on possessing contextual knowledge of the domain in question.

figure.head: Example of a boundary geographical pattern. Visualisation of coordinates assigned to research objects from several British Library collections as viewed in Peripleo. Thanks to Victoria Morris for dataset. (Source: https://britishlibrary.github.io/peripleo-lanc/BL/#/7.08/-1.6498/52.4824/mode=heatmap)

div.p:
The goal of visual analysis might vary from hypothesis testing to hypothesis generation just as the developer’s intention might vary from communicating a geographical argument to stimulating new geographical insights
. Or, humanists might take exception to the epistemological framework that draws such distinctions in the use of visualisations. Yet, in every case, the synoptic task that underlies visual analysis focuses on the visual features of the web map component –projection, vectors and tiles– whilst interactive features play a supporting role, helping the user to explore and find patterns in two visual dimensions. To illustrate this use-case, the article will draw on an interface developed by Fredrik Palm with the assistance of the author as part of the Mapping the Jewish Communities of the Byzantine empire project (MJCBE) funded by the European Research Council. Geography is critical to interpreting the history of these minority communities, and the visualisation of associated geospatial data was intended for visual analysis. The MJCBE interface embeds a web map component, in this case what was Google Maps API, within a set of interactive filters that exist outside the component. Point vectors that represent historical references to the Jewish communities are displayed on a map. The filters allow the user to update the points displayed on the map through combinations of attribute data. Attributes that form filters include place or toponym and date as well as known characteristics of the community like occupation, sect, or residential conditions. The filtering system was designed with the complexity and flexibility to support the display of many permutations of vectors and therefore to afford the generation of unexpected or new geographical patterns. Similarly, the vectors were styled to communicate uncertainty visually and to offer signifiers of issues with the underlying references. Thus, the intention was to stimulate insights into the history of the communities through geography. For example, the interface might offer insights into the relationship between these communities and their changing political and economic contexts within the wider Byzantine empire . Yet the interface only displays data that are directly related to the Jewish communities meaning users would have to draw on their wider knowledge in order to interpret visual patterns. Released in 2013, the interface was available when this article was submitted in early 2023, and will serve as an example of this visual analysis use case throughout the article .

figure.head: Figure 3 Web map component embedded within interactive functionality in the MJCBE interface.

div.p:
In the discussion that follows, MJCBE is used to explore the visual analysis use case. However, MJCBE is representative of many other interfaces that employ web map components for visual analysis. Such interfaces may or may not include complex interactive functionality outside the map like MJCBE. The focus here, however, is on the web map component and how the design of its features might support the visual analysis use case. Examples of interfaces that might be used for visual analysis include:
The Map of Islamophobia Over Time: One of several maps that the Mapping Islamophobia project has created. Here, the style of the vectors and absence of popups suggests that the primary use is the visual analysis of changing geographical patterns through time .
The Mapping Past Societies project: Offers the ability to layer a wealth of historical geospatial data for visual comparison and affords access to attributes in a popup akin to GIS .
Pauliceia 2.0: Focuses on mapping the history of the city of São Paulo offering the ability to view, upload and download GIS data .
Power of Attorney in Oaxaca, Mexico: Maps of legal documents in Mexico. The accompanying text tells us that the resource analyzes and expresses the history of native people’s engagement with Mexico’s colonial and post-independence legal systems by digitally mapping and visualizing social networks and flows of knowledge and power created by legal procedures and litigation. From this process broad trends emerge . Sincere thanks to John Levin for curating a list of DH GIS projects and making these available on the Anterotesis blog . Without this tremendous resource I would not have been able to compile these examples or indeed write this article.

Some of these examples make the intention for visual analysis explicit in text accompanying the web map; for others, the use case can be inferred by using the interface. The developers of each of the examples that follow may not have explicitly intended them to be used for visual analysis, rather an examination of the affordances of their features by the author suggests they support this use case.

div.head: Designing for discovery
div.p: The web map acts as a visual method of accessing digital research objects such as text, images, or sounds in the discovery use case. A suitable dataset must first, include coordinates that represent a geographical characteristic of each object, and second, offer access to rich representations of the objects usually taking the form of URLs pointing to objects hosted within the app or externally. An idealised discovery process consists of two stages. The first stage is interactive including zoom and pan to discover a single vector of interest. The user might have a predetermined idea of what they were looking for resulting in instrumental and purposeful behaviour or, alternatively, behaviour might encompass browsing or exploration. The location that a chosen vector represents may or may not be familiar to the user, meaning domain-specific knowledge is not essential. The second stage is interactive and based on the retrieval of attribute data: in practice, clicking on a vector to trigger a popup, so-called details on demand . The resulting popup might include the research object itself or, more commonly, a hyperlink. The user might be interested in several research objects, in which case they would find their representative vectors sequentially, by clicking on a single vector at a time. The other vectors might help identify a vector of interest, but their relationships are not the focus of cognition. Discovery is therefore based on what Andrienko and Andrienko term elementary tasks. Elementary tasks examine individual elements of the data and, in contrast to synoptic tasks, do not lead to an insight, interpretation, or developed understanding of the phenomenon that the data represents. Both visual analysis and discovery rely on the same set of visual and interactive features within the three-stage iterative process of perception, interaction, and cognition outlined earlier . The key distinction between the use cases lies in the intended focus of cognition: For discovery, the focus is on research objects that can be accessed through the map whilst, in the case of visual analysis, the focus is on the visual features of the map. A map designed for discovery should act as a portal or gateway to research objects. As far as is possible the web map doesn’t intervene as an explanation or argument , although it is acknowledged that this ideal might be unachievable. Discovery is not simply information retrieval. Web maps do not demand queries, they present navigable representations of large digital collections; they invite exploration and support browsing, using overviews to establish context and offer the potential for serendipitous discovery . Yet, the extent to which they can present the complexity and diversity of cultural collections, and to privilege the process of interpretation and can be defined as generous in Mitchell Whitelaw’s terms, is unclear.

This discovery use case will be familiar to researchers from their use of web maps elsewhere, including tasks such as booking accommodation or buying property online. User studies show that Google Maps ‘are no longer used only as a “map”, but also to obtain further information (including opening hours, available goods, prices)’ . Sixty percent of a representative sample of the UK public liked to have practical information about places (e.g. opening hours, pictures, reviews) available to them when using online map interfaces making this the second most popular function after navigation . Discovery aligns with the goals of cultural heritage organisations who are interested in driving traffic to web pages and in encouraging the use of a breadth of digital objects. However, as the examples outline below demonstrate, the use case can also support digital humanities projects. Therefore, to illustrate the discovery use case, the article will draw on Peripleo, a web map interface developed by Rainer Simon with support from Stephen Gadd, Leif Isaksen, and the author as part of the Locating a National Collection project and funded by the UK’s Arts and Humanities Research Council . The interface was designed to help researchers and the wider public to discover web pages that represent the collections of the UK’s cultural heritage organisations. Developers are able to create their own instances of Peripleo based on Linked Data in the form of JSON-LD files. Javascript Object Notation Linked Data. A lightweight human-readable linked-data format for exchanging data on the web. The interface includes search and filtering functionality that updates vectors shown on the map and the colour of their representations. In creating this interface, the development team took design decisions that tailored its use for discovery, and these will be outlined in the remainder of this article.

figure.head: Peripleo web maps interface displaying VisitPlus dataset from Locating a National Collection (https://britishlibrary.github.io/locating-a-national-collection/VisitPlus.html) (Source: )

div.p: Peripleo is representative of several interfaces that support the discovery use case. Whilst the text that accompanies these maps might not detail their intended purpose explicitly, as with the maps intended for visual analysis, potential use can be inferred from the design of features and their affordances. Examples include:

list.item: Charles Booth’s London: Connects Booth’s maps of London with references to geography in pages from Booth’s notebook made available in an International Image Interoperability Framework (iiif) viewer .
Countering Islamaphobia maps: The Mapping Islamaphobia website also makes this map available that offers prominent links to journalism and other sources of information through simple vector markers .
Cleveland Historical: Stories related to locations in Cleveland available from map popups
Danish Manors: Offers access to information on Danish Manors from a simple map interface
Travellers maps: This modern map of traveling, which aims at promoting the "Hellenic world" acts as a gateway to multimedia resources

div.head: Interactive features
div.p:
Decisions taken in designing these features can provide signifiers that emphasise particular affordances. Such signifiers are particularly important as researchers do not necessarily have a use-case in mind. Digital humanities scholarship has argued that assuming users have a predetermined goal is unrealistic and counter-productive
. Rather, users will initially enter into exploratory behaviour to understand how the map might be used in their research. In this exploratory phase, users will draw on their experiences of using similar interfaces elsewhere. However, the user should not be left observing without any clear purpose, rambling through the data in the hope of encountering something interesting, which might provide food for thought and lead to a sudden insight . The developer should have an intended use for the map in mind: Good design communicates this potential use by providing signifiers to guide the user.

The widespread use of web maps leads users to possess pre-existing knowledge of affordances. It is unnecessary to provide signifiers that panning, moving the geographical display of the map, is possible by clicking, holding and moving the mouse laterally or longitudinally. Similarly, users will know that turning the mouse wheel facilitates zooming in and out. However, the developer should always consider constraining the geographical area that can be panned whilst limiting the ability to zoom. The affordance that vectors offer to retrieve attribute data through a click is familiar to users from previous experience. Most would be unsurprised when their click triggers the appearance of a popup in the browser displaying text, a hyperlink, an image or a video. The motivation for retrieving attribute data differs based on use case. In visual analysis, attributes point to evidence on which the argument is based such as dates, sources or people. Although they deepen understanding of the primary synoptic task, their retrieval is a secondary concern. For the discovery use case, the retrieval of attribute data such as URLs that represent research objects is the primary affordance.

The developer has several opportunities to provide signifiers that guide the user. For example, vectors’ representations can be tailored to emphasise that they are clickable by providing a symbol of sufficient size and opacity or by employing tool tips. More complex vector designs such as heatmaps (see Figure 2) or choropleths A thematic map that displays statistical information as colours. afford visual analysis but might obscure the ability to click and retrieve attributes. The use of tiles that are lighter in colour and that contain less detail can emphasise the ability to click on a vector. If the developer intends the map to be used for discovery, simple vector representations are preferable, as they guide the user away from visual analysis and towards the elementary task of finding an individual vector and clicking. For example, the Peripleo interface uses simple circles to emphasise the affordance of clicking. The form in which attribute data are displayed on retrieval should vary depending on use case. Where the attribute data are intended to support visual analysis, their popup display should not obscure the map and those attributes that are relevant to visual analysis can be emphasised. A concise popup, that can be closed easily, offers a simple route to return to the map view preventing the user from leaving the map entirely. In contrast, in the discovery use case, greater emphasis should be placed on the display of attribute data. For instance, a modal that displays attributes whilst deactivating other content on the page was used to good effect in Charles Booth’s London map when this paper was written . The research object or the method of accessing the research object should be emphasised in the display. Hyperlinks that provide access to research objects should be prominent and housed within a button or other clear signifier. In the case of Booth’s map, the modal offers a prominent link to relevant pages from Booth’s notebook.

Signifying the importance of these hyperlinks is the most important consideration when designing for discovery. Furthermore, previews that communicate properties of hyperlinked research objects such as media types like image, video or text should be considered . Finally, as web analytics can capture relevant user interactions including statistics for the opening of popups and subsequent click-throughs to research objects, they offer clear metrics for the use of maps designed for discovery. For example, popups in the Peripleo interface provide prominent hyperlinks in the form of buttons alongside the ability to install web analytics. On the other hand, such metrics were not considered for the MJCBE interface where hyperlinks are less prominent and do not offer access to rich data or relevant research objects. In summary, the importance of retrieving attribute data varies between use cases. The ability to access attributes that represent research objects is critical to discovery. For visual analysis, the retrieval of attribute data only supports the synoptic task that focuses on the visual features of the map. With this key distinction established, the next section will examine the design of visual features and associated signifiers that the developer can use to guide the user.

figure.head: Popup used in Peripleo displaying signifiers of hyperlinks designed for discovery use case.

div.head: Visual features
div.p: Of all the features of the web map component, the developer has the greatest control over vectors, coordinates displayed as markers and other shapes on the map. The vector data consumed by the web map component takes the point, polyline, and polygon forms that are known from GIS. The underlying geometry or coordinates are commonly encoded in WGS84: the most commonly used system for representing locations on the earth’s surface as latitude and longitude. These coordinates then sit within standard data structures designed to share geospatial data on the web that include formats such as GeoJSON, KML or the OGC’s Web Feature Service (WFS). For example, Peripleo is based on the Linked Places standard developed in association with the Pelagios Network. Some DH applications make the underlying datasets available for download, Pauleicia offers this ability providing opportunities for reuse . The coordinates and their associated attributes can be visualised in diverse ways.

A vector dataset is created by modelling geographical characteristics of a research object or objects and metadata. Such characteristics include where the object was created, found or used, or some aspect of its content, broadly defined to include locations mentioned in text or depicted in art. Such geographical modelling is not self-evident or straightforward and the results subjective and partial . Visual communication of the critical relationship between research object and geometry is difficult. The difficulties in using Euclidean geometry to represent place has been extensively discussed in scholarship on GIS and other technologies
. The shortcomings of representing nuanced and complex humanities data within the simplistic demarcation of space that vector geometries provide should be a concern for the developer of a web map. However, the web map component offers significant flexibility to meet this challenge as most cartographic forms of representation can be rendered using standard technologies for rendering graphics in browsers including CSS, D3 or plugins .

figure.head: Issues in defining place using vectors. A visualisation of crowd-sourced neighbourhood mapping from the Boston Neighbourhood Consensus project created by Bostonography. By Andy Woodruff (https://andywoodruff.com) and Tim Wallace (https://www.nytimes.com/by/tim-wallace). (Source https://bostonography.com/2017/official-unofficial-neighborhoods-2017. Used with the permission of the authors.)

div.p: The representation of vectors should vary according to use case in terms of form and style. Web maps offer developers opportunities to configure symbol, shape, colour, or shade to represent attributes and support visual analysis. Users have experience of using particular styles for certain forms of visual analysis, for instance, choropleths in the case of electoral data. The division of a dataset into layers means vectors can be broken down into subsets where differences in representation might communicate relationships . Complexity of visual form might, however, obscure the affordance of clicking on a vector to retrieve attribute data. For example, the MJCBE interface styles vectors using opacity to help users understand spatial and temporal uncertainty in underlying data quickly . As more transparent vector symbols represent greater uncertainty styling obscures the ability to click on a vector’s representation. On the other hand, the simple style of Peripleo markers is intended to guide the user away from making visual comparisons between markers and towards clicking. This article does not attempt to provide a comprehensive guide to these options and their application. Rather, it urges the developer to consider intended use when choosing vector representation and not employ the familiar inverted-drop-shaped pin popularised by Google .

Whilst vectors should be the focus of any web map, tiles dominate the display space, setting the visual tone. Tiles provide an efficient and lightweight method of displaying and updating background maps in the browser based on zoom and pan interactions. Tiles are requested individually based on zoom and pan interactions before being joined seamlessly in the browser. Traditionally made up of geolocated PNG images in 2025 tiles more often take the form of packets of vectors. They are typically served using an HTTP geospatial standard such as Web Map Tile Service (WMTS) defined by the OGC . Rendered as seamless and interactive images they support the familiar, slippy web map format. Many users will be familiar with those made available by commercial providers such as Bing, Google, or MapTiler alongside open offerings like OpenStreetMap. These tiles are often designed to support uses of web maps in society today that include navigation and information retrieval and reflect the commercial interests of providers. The wealth of tiles made available has been extensively researched outside the digital humanities. These tiles are created for particular purposes, for example to generate commercial revenue through advertising. Tiles are complex and multi-layered datasets meaning their production process is not always readily apparent , and biases in design make them unsuitable for particular user needs . Some are not representative or equitable and suffer from deficiencies including the representation of national borders and poor coverage of the global south . The use of many sets of tiles is therefore problematic from political and ethical perspectives. Those offered by commercial providers are by no means the only type of tile that can be displayed within web map components, rather, they represent a default setting. In particular, those projects that examine the global south or adopt a global perspective should consider the alternative options outlined below.

Temporality is a critical consideration in the use of tiles in the digital humanities yet has been little discussed. Designed for use in today’s society, tiles generally depict current geography. Yet humanities research examines varied time periods making the use of many tiles anachronistic. Despite these concerns, such tiles are widely used in digital humanities projects: for example, more than 50 of 76 digital literary mapping projects used such online mapping services . The Mapping Islamaphobia and Power of Attorney in Oaxaca, Mexico projects introduced earlier implement tiles from ESRI and Carto that depict modern topography which is mainly obscured by dark shading, anachronistic in the case of the Power of Attorney in Oaxaca, Mexico project. The MJCBE interface uses Google tiles derived from satellite imagery. Current topography was intended to act as a corollary for topography of the past yet, despite limits placed on zoom to avoid users’ engagement with large scales, the tiles are anachronistic.

figure.head: Anachronistic use of tiles derived from satellite imagery to represent Byzantine period topography in MJCBE interface.

div.p: It is convenient to use tiles that display modern topography as they are packaged up as a service by commercial providers. The creation of tiles and the setup and maintenance of services is labour intensive, making bespoke implementations beyond the reach of many individual projects. Alternatives do exist such as tiles derived from individual digitised maps and made available through services like Allmaps or the Georeferencer or as seamless map layers created by stitching a published series of maps together . Whilst undoubtedly useful, and often a significant improvement, such digitised maps also embody a specific worldview and power dynamic. Many such maps were originally created for navigation and economic planning, to name two examples, and are entangled with historical processes including conflict, colonialism, or empire building. A welcome alternative for an earlier period is provided by the Consortium of Ancient World Mappers who offer tiles with worldwide coverage of topography with water levels adjusted at different dates . Peripleo offers an option within a JSON configuration file to configure the map instance to display selected tiles of choice. Those selected by default are provided by MapTiler, but guidance on adding the Consortium of Ancient World Mappers tiles is available in the form of some simple steps. The role and importance of tiles varies based on use case. Whilst vectors are the focus of visual analysis, tiles are also essential to recognising, interpreting, and deriving meaning from patterns. Therefore, the choice of tile is critical to guiding the user towards visual analysis. Tiles should be chosen to accentuate and to draw attention to markers, for example, by ensuring colours are complementary or that tiles are light in colour thus focusing attention on the markers. In the case of discovery, tiles are simply used for orientation, supporting the user to find, notice, or recognise a single vector. Familiarity with current geographical features like settlements might therefore be helpful and the anachronistic nature of many tilesets need not be detrimental to their use for discovery.

div.head: Projection
div.p:
Projection defines the display of vectors and their relationship to tiles making the choice of projection a critical consideration in designing any web map. A projection is a transformation of the three-dimensional earth onto a two-dimensional map. It is possible to use many different calculations to display or approximate the sphere that is the earth on a flat surface. That map projections should be selected based on their appropriateness for the user’s data, the geographic area being mapped, and the types of measurements that a reader might need to make is a firmly established cartographic principle. Yet, in the vast majority of cases, web map components are setup to use the default spherical, pseudo, or Web Mercator projection known by the code EPSG:3857 . The deficiencies of the projection are well-documented in cartographic literature . Despite this critique, the projection has gained prominence in the twenty-first century on the web. Components including Leaflet, MapBoxGL, and Open Layers offer the opportunity to select from a range of possible projections either using selectors, plugins or bespoke code
. Yet these options are rarely used. Indeed, all of the projects introduced earlier are based on the Web Mercator projection.

div.p: All projections require compromise, and in selecting a projection the cartographer must weigh distortion of area against the distortions of angles, distances and directions . Designed to facilitate the calculation of bearings, the Mercator projection preserves angles, making it conformal. A simplified version has become standard in web maps based on a spherical earth model and differing from modern Mercator implementations used elsewhere that adopt the most accurate earth model available . The earth is not a perfect sphere but rather is irregular. Advanced map projections take this irregularity into account in their transformation. The projection offers significant technical advantages as its uninterrupted, cylindrical form expedites the creation of tiles and makes panning straightforward. Furthermore, the projection’s conformality means the calculations required to plot coordinates are less complex, a desideratum for web services where computational resources have been at a premium historically . Yet these advantages are predicated on compromises elsewhere, and, in the case of Web Mercator, such compromises include distortions to area, shape, and distance. Such distortions also vary depending on latitude. Higher latitudes suffer from increased area and shape distortions meaning that, for example, polygons that are the same area in pixels but located at different latitudes do not represent the same geographical area . The relationship between pixels and distance varies according to latitude and is proportional only along the equator . For instance, it is a common misconception that a straight line or loxodrome represents the shortest distance between two points rather than a great circle . Moreover, the simplification of the earth’s shape that underpins Web Mercator leads to further errors with positions portrayed up to 50km from their correct position at high latitudes . Finally, whilst the projection’s cylindrical nature facilitates east-west panning, interruption at the poles prevents readers from considering trans-polar routes, those that cross the northern and southern edges of the map, when estimating distances between points . Thus, the use of web maps based on the Mercator projection for estimation tasks such as comparing and measuring can lead to incorrect assumptions about geographic distributions and relationships as empirical studies have shown .

div.p: The impact of such compromises varies depending on the dataset in question and the intended use case. The distortions to distance, area, and shape necessary to preserve angles can have a deleterious effect on performing the synoptic task that underpins visual analysis. Distortions to relationships between vectors and tiles affect maps of certain scales more than others. The projection is suited to local geography over global comparison and small-scale maps, those that depict larger geographical areas such as parts of continents, are particularly affected. Visual analysis of any map where the zoom level is less than four according to the standard scale used by Leaflet, Google Maps Embed API, and others, is particularly problematic, and, in such cases, alternatives such as those that preserve area, like Equal Earth , or distance, like World Equidistant cylindrical , should be employed. The total latitude depicted on Mercator maps should be small and not include latitudes above around 60 degrees. Any use of the component that includes a polar region would benefit from using a custom projection, for example, Antarctic Polar Stereographic . In addition to considering the region to be depicted carefully, the map creator should set limits on pan and zoom, to ensure that only map views with minimum distortion are depicted. Vectors and tiles used in the MJCBE interface are projected using Web Mercator. Vectors depicted on the map lie between the latitudes of 44.8 and 24.9 meaning differences in areal distortion between these latitudes are within reasonable limits. Furthermore, the distribution of vectors in terms of both latitude and longitude facilitates relatively accurate estimation of distance. Web Mercator arguably has benefits for the discovery use case where the focus is on locating a particular vector of interest. Familiar to many users, the shape of landmasses and cardinal directions meet preconceptions for how a map should look. Such familiarity expedites the recognition of known geographical areas, fostering an un-intimidating experience .

The concept of distortion may not sit comfortably with humanities researchers for whom representation is inherently subjective. Yet over and above the mechanistic considerations previously outlined, the resulting social and political biases embodied in the distortions of the Mercator projection and its history cannot be ignored. The inflation of particular landmasses such as western Europe at the expense of areas of Africa and Asia came under attack in critical cartographic discourse in the twentieth century. This was not only because such inflation renders maps unsuitable for particular purposes but also because the distortion replicates perceived Western cultural hegemony. In the later twentieth century, this reassessment was taken up as part of the wider post-colonial critique, leading to a significant decline in the projection’s use in print maps such as atlases . Despite this welcome earlier change, the explosion in web mapping has led to a resurgence in the use of the Mercator projection, a trend that has been the subject of some critical discussion
.

Implementations of the web map component, including by the author of this article in co-designing both the Peripleo and MJCBE interfaces, have ignored decades of cartographic reflection on the projection’s political implications. The author has been unable to locate any projects in the digital humanities that use alternative projections within a web map component. Where alternatives projections have been implemented the maps used are either static or bespoke implementations based on the use of canvas or SVG elements with D3 for example. Examples of such maps include:

SlaveVoyages static maps taken from Atlas of the Transatlantic Slave Trade .

div.p: What might account for the lack of alternative projections in web map components? Platforms developed by technology companies including Google’s MyMaps or Carto offer a straightforward route to making interactive maps available by uploading a spreadsheet . These platforms account for many, if not the majority, of digital humanities projects but they do not offer straightforward alternatives to Web Mercator. Thus, there is often a requirement to write bespoke code to implement different projections and the appearance of some tiles within a web map component can deteriorate when reprojected at particular scales. Yet these barriers are by no means insurmountable as many of the web map components that are available in 2024 offer the ability to display maps in different projections . For example, Open Layers is open source and only requires minor changes in configuration to change the display projection. Although there are technical barriers, a lack of cartographic knowledge also prevents the use of alternatives. Calls for an ethical visualisation workflow have urged humanists and developers alike to consider the larger contextual framing and the story that it tells employing a critical perspective on the power of individual design elements . The popularity of web maps arguably makes the Web Mercator projection the most widely used design element in digital humanities visualisation. If any community possesses the knowledge and critical skills to think beyond the confines of a default setting it should be digital humanists. In 2025, the barriers to implementing alternative projections are lower than ever before. Web maps developed in the digital humanities would be much improved by thinking through projections creatively.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p:
The user-centred approach adopted by this article has led to a set of recommendations for designing web maps to support the two use cases. Designing for the discovery use case supports finding and accessing research objects and draws on researchers’ experience of using web maps elsewhere. Discovery aligns with the priorities of the creators of digital research objects including research projects and cultural heritage organisations who are interested in maximising the use of web pages through usage metrics and usability studies. Collections of research objects and the resulting datasets are palimpsests of decisions; their partial, subjective nature might not be suitable for collective interpretation. Designing for discovery can guide the user away from visual analysis and help projects and organisations to present a breadth of research objects. This article suggests that the implementation of web maps for visual analysis requires careful thought. The design of visual features such as vectors, tiles, and projection should be considered in relation to the dataset and aims of the project. These aims do appear to be unclear for many projects for which simply making a map available appears to be the main goal. The article’s perspective on visual analysis has been cultivated in response to the author’s work on MJCBE. Here, the web map component and associated interactive functionality were designed to support visual analysis. Yet use of the interface for this purpose has not proven straightforward and relies on significant background knowledge of the Byzantine empire. There have been few citations that record usage of the MJCBE interface for its intended purpose in the decade since release which raises the question of how to measure the success or effectiveness of web maps in the visual analysis use case. This article does not argue that every web map could be designed exclusively for visual analysis or discovery. Maps might serve both purposes or others such as the visualisation of a single narrative, journey, or marker or offering access to statistical information such as calculating routes in the past
. Rather, considering both use cases in relation to modelling of data and an intended audience of users represents a useful exercise in planning and design.

Future work, encompassing a systematic investigation of more projects that have used web map components could categorise implementations in terms of their data type, theme or subject, vector representation, and other characteristics leading to further definitions of use cases. The article has adopted a mechanistic or instrumentalist perspective focused on activities, tasks, and features – a perspective which might be considered to be at odds with recent digital humanities literature that persuasively argues for a reconsideration of the task-based or goal-oriented paradigm that has pervaded user experience or visualisation research . Yet characteristics of the web map component itself justify the article’s perspective. Its intended and primary usage is mobility, planning and navigation within the physical environment. Researchers will bring learned behaviours of task-based use to any web map, and the discovery activity aligns with such experience of using web maps elsewhere. The article argues that if the component is used for visual analysis, the developer must consider the wider use of web maps, as processes of knowing through interpretative work … are also the expression of particular circumstances of production . Whilst the article is titled Designing for Discovery, developing signifiers of the potential for visual analysis is just as important. The need for alternative methods of visualisation has been stressed over the last decade under the suggestion that data visualizations have depended on impoverished methods… current practices of reductive graphs and standard charts have debased interpretation, made it simplistic and literal. We know better and can do more . The web map component’s constrained set of features, two-dimensional visualisation and flat and tightly-defined data model call into question its suitability for many forms of open-ended, enjoyable or playful exploration. For example, possible user journeys are limited leading narrative or story maps to often rely on several different maps.

Alternative methods of creating maps on the web offer greater flexibility. Bespoke maps based on Canvas or SVG are commonly used in fields such as data journalism and alternative forms suggested in the digital humanities include the space-time cube or deep maps . Yet these alternatives require greater effort and expertise to deploy. Whilst the web map component’s simplicity has led to its proliferation such simplicity also has disadvantages in terms of flexibility. The technology cannot be used to create the varied maps available in GIS or more flexible web technologies. Moreover, ease of deployment hampers thinking processes leading to a lack of spatial literacy or reasoning . The developer is completely separated from the inner workings of the component, installing the user at a level of abstraction far above whatever theoretical claims might lie beneath . This separation has stymied the process of critical thinking and experimentation for both user and creator that is valued in the digital humanities . Tutorials based on the component emphasise skills related to web technologies which, whilst undoubtedly useful, are offered at the expense of cartographic knowledge or GIScience. Implementation has been driven by technology and not the open-ended and complex questions that humanities scholars ask. By looking beyond the web map component digital humanists have the means to transform the role of geography in the humanities research process.
